{"comments": {"id": 27543, "count": 19, "talk_id": 4366}, "threadId": 27543, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "4366", "description": "In 2011, Teresa Njoroge was convicted of a financial crime she didn't commit -- the result of a long string of false accusations, increasing bribe attempts and the corrupt justice system in her home in Kenya. Once incarcerated, she discovered that most of the women and girls locked up with her were also victims of the same broken system, caught in a revolving door of life in and out of prison due to poor education and lack of economic opportunity. Now free and cleared by the courts of appeal, Njoroge shares how she's giving women in prison the skills, tools and support they need to break the cycle of poverty and crime and build a better life.", "event": "TEDWomen 2017", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Teresa Njoroge: What I learned serving time for a crime I didn't commit", "slug": "teresa_njoroge_what_i_learned_serving_time_for_a_crime_i_didn_t_commit", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "3618", "slug": "teresa_njoroge", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Teresa", "lastname": "Njoroge", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Criminal and social justice reform advocate", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/40b7aa7debe59f940d0bdb64275a7b30c06df434_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "At Clean Start Kenya, Teresa Njoroge builds bridges connecting the formerly imprisoned to the outside world and vice versa.", "whylisten": "

Teresa Njoroge is the cofounder and CEO of Clean Start Kenya. She was pursuing her childhood dream, a career in banking, when she was falsely accused of a fraudulent transaction. Sentenced to imprisonment in the High Security Langata Women’s Maximum Prison, Njoroge was forced to bring her three-month-old baby with her.

What began as a loss of career and social standing led to her purpose in life, advocating for Kenyan women, youth and men trapped in a cycle of poverty, survival, petty crimes and life behind bars and equipping them with entrepreneurial skills, jobs and formal education. Later cleared of any wrongdoing, Njoroge is now a beacon of hope and second chances to thousands, with her mission to build up the bottom-of-the-pyramid economy and an inclusive Africa. As she writes: "I am an optimistic, self-driven social entrepreneur with over a decade of progressive experience in economic and social justice work, in my journey from 'I can do it' to 'I did it'!"

"}], "url": "https://www.ted.com/talks/teresa_njoroge_what_i_learned_serving_time_for_a_crime_i_didn_t_commit", "viewed_count": 1262446, "talks": [{"recommendations": {"status": "approved", "headline": "Teresa Njoroge recommends", "blurb": "Further reading curated by Teresa Njoroge", "start_at": null, "end_at": null, "published": true, "eyebrow": "", "type": "recommendation", "rec_lists": [{"title": "", "description": "", "rec_items": [{"label": "READ_Book", "headline": "*Incarceration Nations: A Journey to Justice in Prisons Around the World*", "blurb": "This is a unique hybrid of a book, made from various genres: memoir, travelogue, cultural study, academic research. Baz does a great job to educate and inform while taking readers on a rich global journey, of human stories—all in an effort to put a human face on a worldwide justice struggle. It was such an honor to meet Baz this November, 2017 at the [Female Imprisonment Worldwide](http://www.prisonstudies.org/sites/default/files/resources/downloads/invitation_and_programme_wfil_final.pdf) event in London, where I was a speaker.", "note": "Baz Dreisinger Other Press, 2017", "link_url": "", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "READ_Book", "headline": "*Just Mercy: A Story of Justice and Redemption*", "blurb": "I had the honor of meeting Bryan Stevenson, both being speakers at the [Acumen Global gathering](https://acumen.org/blog/acumen-fellows-global-gathering-set-to-convene-300-social-entrepreneurs/) in Naivasha, Kenya in March 2017. Bryan Stevenson whom Desmond Tutu calls 'America's Mandela', has devoted his life to exposing racial bias in the US penal system. In this memoir, true story about the redeeming potential of mercy, Bryan personalises the struggle against injustice. ", "note": "Bryan Stevenson Spiegel & Grau, 2015", "link_url": "https://www.amazon.com/Just-Mercy-Story-Justice-Redemption/dp/081298496X/ref=as_li_tf_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=0520271440&linkCode=as2&tag=teco06-20", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "READ_Article", "headline": ""100 Women: From prison to profit"", "blurb": "To mark the BBC World Service 100 Women season, Caroline Bayley speaks to six former women prisoners, across three continents. They were convicted under different circumstances and of different crimes - but they are united in their passion for business enterprise and self-employment which has allowed them to turn their lives around on the outside. Teresa Njoroge and one of the women beneficiaries of [Clean Start](http://cleanstart.co.ke/), are among those featured. You can listen to the women featured in this article [here](http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p04k007p). ", "note": "Caroline Bayley BBC, 2016", "link_url": "http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-38315132", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "READ_Article", "headline": ""PRISON: Evidence of its use and overuse from around the world"", "blurb": "Clean Start participated at the Understanding and Reducing the Use of Imprisonment Worldwide event, held by the Institute for Criminal Policy Research, Birkbeck University of London.", "note": "Jessica Jacobson, Catherine Heard, Helen Fair Institute for Criminal Policy Research and Fair Trials, 2017", "link_url": "http://www.icpr.org.uk/media/43410/global_imprisonment_web_final.pdf", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}]}]}, "more_resources": [], "corrections": [], "has_citations": true, "take_action": [{"status": "approved", "blurb": "**Learn more** about Clean Start Kenya, a non-profit helping to restore hope, dignity, self-confidence and self-respect to girls and women as they leave prison.", "link_url": "http://cleanstart.co.ke/", "visible_url": "cleanstart.co.ke", "start_at": null, "end_at": null, "published": true, "eyebrow": "", "type": "take_action", "verb": "learn"}], "curator_approved": true, "description": "In 2011, Teresa Njoroge was convicted of a financial crime she didn't commit -- the result of a long string of false accusations, increasing bribe attempts and the corrupt justice system in her home in Kenya. "is_published": true, "firstname": "Teresa", "lastname": "Njoroge", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Criminal and social justice reform advocate", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/40b7aa7debe59f940d0bdb64275a7b30c06df434_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "At Clean Start Kenya, Teresa Njoroge builds bridges connecting the formerly imprisoned to the outside world and vice versa.", "whylisten": "

Teresa Njoroge is the cofounder and CEO of Clean Start Kenya. She was pursuing her childhood dream, a career in banking, when she was falsely accused of a fraudulent transaction. Sentenced to imprisonment in the High Security Langata Women’s Maximum Prison, Njoroge was forced to bring her three-month-old baby with her.

What began as a loss of career and social standing led to her purpose in life, advocating for Kenyan women, youth and men trapped in a cycle of poverty, survival, petty crimes and life behind bars and equipping them with entrepreneurial skills, jobs and formal education. Later cleared of any wrongdoing, Njoroge is now a beacon of hope and second chances to thousands, with her mission to build up the bottom-of-the-pyramid economy and an inclusive Africa. As she writes: "I am an optimistic, self-driven social entrepreneur with over a decade of progressive experience in economic and social justice work, in my journey from 'I can do it' to 'I did it'!"

author: Teresa_Njoroge;
title: What I learned serving time for a crime I didn't commit

aws-transcripts.transcript: When I hade those buzz slum heart, I knew it was for real. I feel confused. I feel betrayed. I feel overwhelmed. I feel silenced. What just happened?
